dt.t: {wi}defeated{/wi} their archrivals in the championship game
The bill was {wi}defeated{/wi} in the Senate.

pt: {sc}conquer{/sc} {sc}vanquish{/sc} {sc}defeat{/sc} {sc}subdue{/sc} {sc}reduce{/sc} {sc}overcome{/sc} {sc}overthrow{/sc} mean to get the better of by force or strategy. {sc}conquer{/sc} implies gaining mastery of.

pt.t: {it}vanquished{/it} the enemy and ended the war

pt: {sc}defeat{/sc} does not imply the finality or completeness of {sc}vanquish{/sc} which it otherwise equals.

pt.t: the Confederates {it}defeated{/it} the Union forces at Manassas
{it}subdued{/it} the native tribes after years of fighting

pt: {sc}reduce{/sc} implies a forcing to capitulate or surrender.

pt.t: the city was {it}reduced{/it} after a month-long siege

pt: {sc}overcome{/sc} suggests getting the better of with difficulty or after hard struggle.
{sc}overthrow{/sc} stresses the bringing down or destruction of existing power.

et: Middle English {it}defeten, defaiten{/it} "to ruin, destroy, nullify," in part verbal derivative of {it}defet{/it} "disfigured, null and void (in law)," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}defait, defet, desfet,{/it} past participle of {it}defaire, desfaire{/it} "to undo, put an end to, destroy, nullify," from {it}de-, des-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}faire{/it} "to do, make," going back to Latin {it}facere{/it}; in part borrowed from Anglo-French {it}defeter,{/it} derivative of {it}defet{/it} {ma}{mat|fact|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}frustration by nullification or by prevention of success

dt.t: The bill suffered {wi}defeat{/wi} in the Senate.

dt: {bc}an overthrow especially of an army in battle

dt.t: his first {wi}defeat{/wi} as a professional boxer
… upon whose property and most dear life a damned {wi}defeat{/wi} was made.

et: in part noun derivative of {et_link|defeat:1|defeat:1}, in part borrowed from Middle French {it}defaite,{/it} noun derivative from feminine of {it}defait,{/it} past participle of {it}defaire, desfaire{/it} "to undo, destroy, kill" {ma}{mat|defeat:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: frustration by nullification or by prevention of success
an overthrow especially of an army in battle

dt.t: It would {it}defeat the purpose of{/it} having a nice car if you never got to drive it.

dt: {bc}to admit that one has been defeated

dt.t: Although she did poorly in the first round, she has refused to {it}admit defeat{/it}.

shortdef: to admit that one has been defeated
to admit one has been defeated

dt.t: The bill {it}went down to defeat{/it} in the House.

shortdef: to fail or lose : to be defeated

dt.t: Even {it}in defeat{/it}, he was a hero to those who loved the sport.

dt: {bc}the position of being close to losing

dt.t: The team was able to snatch victory from {it}the jaws of defeat{/it} by scoring in the final seconds of the game.

shortdef: the position of being close to losing
